algorithm.definition: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations
examples: The sorting algorithm efficiently organized the data
Machine learning algorithms can recognize patterns
algorithm.etymology: From Arabic al-Khwarizmi, named after the 9th-century mathematician

quantum.definition: The minimum amount of any physical entity involved in an interaction
examples: Quantum mechanics describes the behavior of matter at atomic scales
A quantum of light is called a photon

consciousness.definition: The state of being aware of and able to think about one's existence, sensations, thoughts, and surroundings
examples: Human consciousness remains one of the greatest mysteries
The patient regained consciousness after surgery
consciousness.etymology: From Latin conscientius meaning 'knowing with others'

artificial.definition: Made or produced by human beings rather than occurring naturally
examples: Artificial intelligence mimics human cognitive functions
The artificial flowers looked surprisingly real

intelligence.definition: The ability to acquire and apply knowledge and skills
examples: Emotional intelligence is as important as academic intelligence
The spy gathered intelligence about enemy movements

mathematics.definition: The abstract science of number, quantity, and space
examples: Mathematics is the language of science
She excelled in advanced mathematics
mathematics.etymology: From Greek mathematikos meaning 'fond of learning'

philosophy.definition: The study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence
examples: Ancient Greek philosophy laid the foundation for Western thought
His philosophy of life emphasized compassion
philosophy.etymology: From Greek philosophia meaning 'love of wisdom'

science.definition: The intellectual and practical activity encompassing the systematic study of the structure and behavior of the physical and natural world
examples: Science has revolutionized our understanding of the universe
Computer science combines mathematics and engineering

technology.definition: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes
examples: Modern technology has transformed communication
Renewable energy technology is advancing rapidly

programming.definition: The process of creating a set of instructions that tell a computer how to perform a task
examples: Programming requires logical thinking and attention to detail
She learned programming to build mobile apps
